data.name: Mapping and Monitoring of Coffee Forests Group Page

elements.name: el1503957437440
elements.label: Hero Headline
elements.microcopy: This is the text that appears over the image at the top of the page.

elements.name: el1503957437441
elements.label: Hero Deck
elements.value: Identifying innovative ways to map and monitor the extent of coffee and forests — and how they are changing over time.
elements.microcopy: This is the text that appears under the headline above.

elements.name: el1503957437442
elements.label: Body Text Intro
elements.value: Coffee grows in and among tropical forests but this relationship is complex and is changing rapidly. To identify risks and opportunities and to target our investments, we need maps of coffee production areas and forest areas, and knowledge of shade systems.
elements.microcopy: Body text starts here. If you don't have any subheads, you can paste all of the text here; if you want to use subheads, use the following fields to break up the copy accordingly.

elements.name: el1503957437443
elements.label: Subhead 1
elements.microcopy: This is your first subhead. All of these are optional (but encouraged!)

elements.name: el1503957437444
elements.label: Body Text 1
elements.value:
Our goal is to better understand the current area under coffee production and monitor how this is changing over time.

Partners in this Action Network are working together to develop a coffee and forest mapping and monitoring toolkit that enables us to:

  1. Identify where coffee poses the greatest risk of forest loss or opportunity for reforestation
  2. Understand coffee production systems, their prevalence and how they are shifting
  3. Monitor changes in coffee and forest cover in target landscapes

elements.label: 2 column bulleted list 1
elements.value:
1. 35 North Coffee*
  2. African Fine Coffee Association (AFCA)*
  3. Arizona State University*
  4. Caffe Ibis Coffee Roasting Co.*
  5. Center for Coffee Research and Education*
  6. Conservation International*
  7. Fairtrade International
  8. Hesselink Koffie*
  9. International Center for Tropical Agriculture (CIAT)*
  10. Pur Projet*
  11. Rainforest Alliance*
  12. Smithsonian Bird Friendly*
  13. Starbucks*
  14. The Coffee Source*
  15. The Sustainability Consortium*
  16. Tuungane Women's Coffee Cooperative*
  17. UTZ*
  18. Valuing Nature
  19. World Coffee Research (WCR)*

elements.name: el1503957437446
elements.label: Body Text 2
elements.value:
Climate change could cut suitable area for coffee in half by 2050. Remaining suitable areas will be at higher altitudes — areas that often harbor the last remaining intact tropical forests. Coffee can help conserve these forests, or it can put pressure on them.

Monitoring coffee production in relation to forest cover is important to better understand its footprint and to identify areas where coffee has an opportunity to contribute to reforestation and where it poses greatest risk for deforestation.
